title: Cameron and Miliband at PMQs â as it happened | Politics | The Guardian
summary: new statesman loses faith in ed miliband .
pmqs - verdict from the twitter commentariat .

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: jean-claude juncker , the new president of the european commission has said that david cameron has a poor relationship with some other eu leaders .
speaking at his first press conference , he also appeared to accuse cameron and matteo renzi , the italian prime minister , of misrepresenting what happened at an eu meeting .
he said he did not like the way certain prime ministers reacted after demands for extra cash were unveiled at the recent eu summit .
i took notes and when i compared what they had said inside the room with what they said outside , they did not tally up i have no problem with mr renzi , who i appreciate greatly .
i do n't have a problem with mr cameron .
mr cameron has a problem with the other prime ministers .
in other remarks that may have been aimed at the uk , juncker also said he would hit back if anyone criticised the commission .
i will not hide from you that i have a firm intention to react to all unjustified criticisms directed at the commission , wherever they come from .
i am a not a man who trembles before prime ministers or other senior figures .
i accept people criticising the commission , because i myself had many criticisms to make when i was n't yet commission president .
but i do not accept unjustified criticisms , everybody needs to know that .
there will no longer be attacks on the commission without a reaction .
eu officials have suggested that britain could be allowed to pay the â£ 1.7bn it owes the eu in interest-free instalments , and not all at once by 1 december as originally proposed .
british military officers are heading back to iraq to help train and advise the country 's army in its fight against islamic state , the government has confirmed .
lady warsi , the conservative former chairman , has said the party will lose the muslim vote at the next election .
asked if the party was dead in the water with regard to the muslim vote next may , she told the bbc this was a pretty fair assessment .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .
jean-claude juncker chairing the first meeting of the new european commission today .
news agency/rex

documents.title: a rochester byelection round-up
text: and here 's a rochester and strood byelection round-up .
mark reckless , the ukip candidate , has described tory claims that he changed his stance on a controversial housing development in the constituency as a lie .
chris bryant , who is running the labour campaign in the constituency , has said rochester has done a u-turn .
chris bryant ( @ chrisbryantmp ) .
@ markreckless explain this speech then chris bryant ( @ chrisbryantmp ) .
@ markreckless you called lodge hill 'a shovel ready project that wd deliver 5,000 much needed homes being delayed by a government agency ' chris bryant ( @ chrisbryantmp ) .
@ markreckless you said key comparison was between '84 nightingales and homes for 12,000 people and jobs for a further 5,000 people ' chris bryant ( @ chrisbryantmp ) .
@ markreckless so the truth is , you backed the lodge hill development .
chris bryant ( @ chrisbryantmp ) so @ twitterid do n't treat the voters like fools .
own up .
you supported lodge hill , bedroom tax and cameron 's nhs privatisation .
end of .
sajid javid , the culture secretary , has been campaigning for the tories in the constituency .
sajid javid mp ( @ sajidjavid ) seeing first hand amazing norman architecture @ twitterid with the wonderful @ twitterid ukip have accused the tories of putting up campaign posters in a graveyard .
chris irvine ( @ cgi247 ) `` @ michael heaver : appalled that in rochester & strood the conservatives have put up boards in a graveyard

documents.title: a scottish labour leadership round-up
text: here 's a scottish labour leadership round-up .
unite has announced that it is backing neil findlay for the scottish labour leadership .
jim murphy has used a post on his blog to say that , if elected leader , he will allow all factions in the party to play a role .
i want a scotland where we do n't judge people by whether they were a yes voter or a no voter in the referendum .
i will take the same approach with my party as i do about my country .
if i 'm elected scottish labour leader i will bring everyone together .
once the contest is over it 's finished no matter how individual members and trade unionists vote in this contest we will all be on the same side .
each of us is determined to get rid of both the uk and scottish governments .
we are fortunate in this contest to have three strong candidates .
if people support neil or sarah , i want those supporters and ideas in our team .
if people consider themselves to be old labour or new labour , they will still have a role to play in the scottish labour party that i want to lead .
and if people consider themselves to be left wing or right wing , they will still have a role to play in the scottish labour party that i want to lead .
new or old , left or right .
i do n't care which you are .
if your goal is to elect a scottish labour party that wants to tackle the big challenges facing our country then we can work together .
gordon mckay , unison 's labour link chair , has said his union wants findlay to win because , unlike murphy , he has not been a career politician .
mckay was speaking to buzzfeed .

gordon mckay , the labour link chair of unison , said his union chose to back neil findlay msp 's bid rather than murphy 's because findlay does n't come from a political elite , and did n't start off with his career in politics .
neil findlay is capable of getting our message out , said mckay .
he 's been a brick layer , a teacher , a local councillor before he got into holyrood .
he knows exactly what issues affect working people and their families .
rob marchant at labour uncut says unite is opposed to murphy because it knows he would weaken its power in scotland .
findlay has been visiting the uk parliament to campaign .
kevin maguire ( @ kevin maguire ) @ neil findlaymsp is in the house .
the main challenger to @ twitterid for the scottish labour crown is campaigning in the uk parliament cailean gallagher at left futures says murphy would be disastrous for labour .

documents.title: new statesman loses faith in ed miliband
text: this week 's new statesman will make for grim reading in ed miliband 's office .
traditionally the new statesman is a beacon for fabian , metropolitan labourism - ie , ed miliband 's brand of politics - and it backed him for the labour leadership in 2010 .
now , though , it 's not so sure .
in its cover story , headlined on the front running out of time , george eaton concludes that unable to inspire itself , labour has never seemed further from inspiring the country .
here 's an extract .
no mp i have spoken to has argued that the labour leader 's parlous ratings are n't a problem or dismissed them as a westminster bubble issue .
we 're all very , very concerned .
the reality is that whilst we do n't have a presidential system , people are thinking increasingly about who they want to be the prime minister , one shadow minister said .
he went on to describe a sobering moment in which a voter told him : you 've been a fantastic mp , but i 'm not going to vote for you .
because ed 's not prime ministerial .

it did focus my own mind around the fact that you can be a good mp locally and well respected and even though it will be your name on the ballot paper , people will go into the polling booth mindful of who they want to do the top job , he added one senior mp suggested that miliband should abandon westminster , save for prime minister 's questions , and go on a rolling tour of marginal constituencies .
the 200-400 voters in key seats who say on the doorstep that he 's the problem , he could win them round by talking to them .
but he doubted whether miliband had the will to do so .
his confidence has gone .
it 's like a light 's gone out , he lamented .
in a separate article jason cowley , the magazine 's editor , argues that miliband is not connecting with voters .
miliband is very much an old-style hampstead socialist .
he does n't really understand the lower middle class or material aspiration .
he does n't understand essex man or woman .

politics for him must seem at times like an extended ppe seminar : elevated talk about political economy and the good society miliband does not have a compelling personal story to tell the electorate , as thatcher did about her remarkable journey from the grocer 's shop in grantham and the values that sustained her along the way or alan johnson does about his rise from an impoverished childhood in west london .
i went to oxford to study ppe , worked for gordon brown , became a cabinet minister and then leader of the party does not quite do it .
none of this would matter were miliband in manner and approach not so much the product of this narrow background .
he understands and has analysed astutely capitalism 's destructive potential but not perhaps its resilience and ability to absorb shocks .
as lenin said , there are no absolutely hopeless situations for capitalism , as we are again discovering .
there are deep problems for labour and for all social-democratic parties that transcend any one leader .
but as we enter an unstable era of multiparty politics , the fragmentation of the british state and intensifying euroscepticism , miliband 's chief problem is not policy but tone .
he needs to find a distinctive voice to articulate people 's feelings about the present moment .
and he might have to accept before long or the electorate will force him to that europe 's social-democratic moment , if it ever existed , is fading into the past .
new statesman cover statesman

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: ed miliband has accused david cameron of being a do n't know prime minister over europe .
he made the claim at pmqs after cameron three times refused to rule out campaign for an out vote in a referendum on britain 's membership of the eu .

miliband said british business would be holding its head in its hands over cameron 's words your renegotiation is going nowhere , you 're caught between backbenchers who want to leave and our national interest which demands we stay .
that 's why on europe you dare n't say yes and dare n't say no .
you 're a do n't know prime minister .
but cameron insisted that he had a plan for an eu renegotation .
he said he was offering a referendum , unlike labour , and he accused miliband of weak leadership i could n't be more clear .
i want britain to stay in a reformed european union and , unlike the party opposite , we have a plan to get that reform and hold that referendum .
this comes at the end of a week when the last labour chancellor has said the tories are right over a referendum .
it comes at the end of a week when the shadow deputy leader of the house has said labour is in a dreadful position .
and it comes at the end of a week when even john prescott has said they have a problem in that they ca n't communicate in english .
that is the case - when you get a lecture from john prescott on the english language , you 're really in trouble .
cameron has said that no libyan soldiers involved in a training programme at a cambridgeshire army base should be granted asylum to remain in the uk .

speaking at pmqs , he labelled the events at bassingbourn barracks as completely unacceptable , and said the heard of the armed forces would investigate the involvement of some of the libyans in criminal actions .

sajid javid , the culture secretary , has said he is willing to legislate to force mobile phone companies to eradicate signal black spots , despite a leaked letter from theresa may , the home secretary , warning that it could make it more difficult to track terrorists .

lutfur rahman , the mayor of tower hamlets , has hit back at claims he has behaved like a medieval monarch dispensing funds to favoured ethnic minority groups , saying the attacks are fuelled by a political class embarrassed by the success of his brand of community politics .
downing street has said an eu report saying up to ¬7bn of the eu 's budget is mis-spent underlines the need for significant reforms .
as the press assocation reports , the european court of auditors ( eca ) has issued another scathing assessment of the handling of the ¬117 billion budget .
it put the error rate - european taxpayers ' money wrongly spent via the eu - at between 3.5 % and 5.9 % , a total of somewhere between ¬4bn and ¬7bn .
the prime minister 's spokesman said : is this further evidence of the importance of going further in reforms of the eu and eu budget accountability ?
absolutely it is .
it is one of the many reasons why the prime minister has sought to reduce the eu budget .
lord ashcroft has published a fresh poll of tory marginal seats that suggests ed miliband is on course to become prime minister .
here 's an extract from his analysis .
in my previous round of battleground polling , published last month , i looked at eleven constituencies where the conservatives have majorities of up to 4.8 % over labour .

i found that nine of them would change hands on the basis of my snapshots , with swings to labour ranging from 2 % to 8 % , averaging 5 % in the seats as a whole as i explained in the commentary on my previous round of marginals research , this leaves the magic number ( the combined number of net conservative losses and net labour gains required for the two parties to have the same number of seats after the election ) at 46 .
if the total is less than 46 , the tories remain the largest party ; if it is more than 46 , the largest party will be labour .

since my research so far has shown the conservatives and labour ahead in equal numbers of seats currently held by the lib dems , and ukip ahead in two seats currently held by the tories , the conservatives can afford to lose no more than 21 seats to labour if they are to remain the largest party .
my battleground polling has to date found them behind in 38 albeit sometimes by very slim margins and we have not yet reached the point at which the tory losses end .
vince cable is announcing â£ 67m of funding to support british inventors who want to turn their ideas into commercial products .
unite , the uk 's largest union , has backed neil findlay as labour 's next scottish leader .

pat rafferty , unite leader in scotland , said : after consultation with our members ' representatives , the clear outcome is that unite 's recommendation to our members is to back neil findlay msp for leader of the labour party in scotland .
neil 's impressive record of working for working people and their communities at holyrood and in his role as shadow health minister won the day .
in neil we are confident that our members will find a leader who not only understands their concerns but will fight doggedly on their behalf .
they can be assured that neil is on their side .

documents.title: pmqs - verdict from the twitter commentariat
text: and here 's what political journalists are saying about pmqs .

journalists saying or implying cameron won sun politics ( @ sun politics ) today 's 'dead parrot ' of a # pmqs on the eu handed @ twitterid cameron a 4-2 win over @ twitterid miliband nicholas watt ( @ nicholaswatt ) blows may have been low , may have lost on substance but final @ twitterid cameron response to @ twitterid miliband shows 20 yrs exp prepping for # pmqs james forsyth ( @ jgforsyth ) another week where the cameron miliband exchanges do n't advance political debate .
but it is now cameron who is happier to run down the clock journalists saying or implying miliband won john rentoul ( @ johnrentoul ) do n't agree with scoring # pmqs but ed miliband won that 6-0 .
jeremy cliffe ( @ jeremycliffe ) strong pmqs performance from ed m. labour knows that compared with tory brexit risk , energy price freeze/mansion tax insignificant to biz .
gaby hinsliff ( @ gabyhinsliff ) fwiw that # pmqs was a clear win for edm : tory mps well aware the holding line on eu is n't really holding .

( which is n't much , tbh ) jonathan walker ( @ jonwalker121 ) cameron incoherent on europe at # pmqs - a win for ed miliband this week general comments isabel hardman ( @ isabelhardman ) ed miliband asks a good question - who is really on cameron 's side in europe ?
# pmqs `` we have a plan , he has no plan ! ''
says dc iain martin ( @ iainmartin1 ) even the participants in # pmqs look as though they realise it is a counter-productive charade .
iain martin ( @ iainmartin1 ) half-hearted tory shouts of `` more '' after cam/milie exchanges .
less is more .
that was absolutely dire all round .
# pmqs craig woodhouse ( @ craigawoodhouse ) # pmqs incredibly flat today .
tories half hearted in cheering cam as he reels off quotes on labour woes .
matt chorley ( @ mattchorley ) cameron : `` your party is rubbish . ''
miliband : `` your party is rubbish . ''

the polls suggest voters agree with them both # pmqs jason groves ( @ jasongroves1 ) 3 - number of times cameron ducks question of whether he might campaign to leave the eu if his renegotiation fails # pmqs joe murphy ( @ joemurphylondon ) mili : `` he is a nothing leader '' .
cam : `` he 's a do n't know prime minister '' .
does # pmqs get any worse ?
joncraigsky ( @ joncraig ) nick clegg looked particularly miserable at pmqs as cam & mili traded blows on eu .
i thought i almost spotted a nod during mili questions .
sam macrory ( @ sammacrory ) chickens and parrots got outings at # pmqs today , but the whole thing had more of a dodo feel about it .

did n't take flight james chapman ( mail ) ( @ jameschappers ) that eu-tastic # pmqs just gave cameron a taste of first 2 years of next parliament if he wins the election # bangingon stephen bush ( @ stephenkb ) not a commentary on ed but once the leader of the opposition shuts up , # pmqs improves immeasurably .
george eaton ( @ georgeeaton ) two labour questions on vat rise today ; will be a key election attack line .

# pmqs james forsyth ( @ jgforsyth ) telling that cameron says 'ulster ' in reply to a question from paisley jr , tories keen to keep dup sweet in case of another hung parliament nick robinson ( @ bbcnickrobinson ) reason @ twitterid miliband asked pm again & again if he 'd vote yes or no to eu = to split tories as many urging pm to say he 'd vote no if no reform
i 'll put up a post soon with pmq tweets from the commentariat , but this , from the ukip mep patrick o'flynn , is also worth a mention .
patrick o'flynn ( @ oflynnmep ) another big win for nigel farage at pmqs today and he does n't even have to attend - phenomenally efficient use of time and resources .
david cameron has a very poor record at quoting people out of context at pmqs , but ed miliband is n't always innocent either .
at pmqs today miliband says cameron used to say he would never be in favour of leaving the european union .
labour have been handing out the source for this assertion , a daily telegraph interview with cameron from july 2012 saying cameron says he will never campaign for an out vote in any referendum .
but the never is journalistic gloss , because cameron 's quote does not include the word .
here 's the paragraph with the key quote .
i think it would be bad for britain , [ cameron ] says .
when i look at what is in our national interest , we are not some country that looks in on ourself or retreats from the world .
britain 's interest trading a vast share of our gdp is to be in those markets .
not just buying , selling , investing , receiving investment but also helping to write the rules .
if we were outside , we would n't be able to do that .

documents.title: pmqs verdict
text: pmqs verdict : do you remember when labour was worried about talking about an eu referendum ?
and when it was said that one of ed miliband 's biggest decisions was whether or not to match the tory offer to hold them ?
at that point the eu was certainly a tory issue .

but miliband has now made his decision ( it 's a no ) and now he is very confident about exploiting europe as an issue , partly because this is labour 's best pro-business policy but mainly because it is a means of exposing the fundamental split in the conservative party , between the inners and the outers , that cameron is struggling to contain .
miliband mounted his attack rather well .

his opening question was funny and pointed , he successfully illustrated how cameron has shifted his position ( by challenging him to repeat his line about not backing an out vote - cameron refused ) and his line about having the same policy on europe as cameron until cameron lost control of his party was powerful because it was true .
my position on the referendum is exactly the same as yours was before you lost control of your party .
but cameron was good too .

his use of the thomas docherty quote from last week was grotesquely unfair , because it was about state of the scottish labour party , not the uk labour party , but his use of the alistair darling quote was perfectly legitimate , and his final joke about john prescott was effective too .

some readers will take the view that you should not be allowed to win an exchange unless you can win the intellectual argument , but life , politics , theatre and advertising ( all of which are contained in pmqs ) does n't quite work like that , and my judgment is that a neutral person listening would have felt that cameron saw off the miliband attack .
and that 's it .
a substantial verdict coming up soon
labour 's keith vaz says next friday is world diabetes day .
will cameron introduced measures to reduce the amount of sugar in food and drink .
cameron says vaz is right to raise this issue .
diabetes-related complications cost the nhs billions of pounds a year .
vaz also wants him to light his home blue , he says .
he says he is all in favour of that , and hopes to keep it like that for some years to come .
pauline latham , a conservative , asks cameron to congratulate the volunteers who helped to make the poppies on display at the tower of london .
cameron says it is an extraordinary display .
labour 's michael meacher says cameron likes to bang on about labour over-spending .
until 2008 labour 's highest deficit was 3.3 % .
but the thatcher/major government ran higher deficits in 10 years .
cameron says there is only one problem with meacher 's question ; when labour left office , the defict was over 11 % .
martin horwood , a lib dem mp , says the 90 % superfast broadband target is not high enough .
cameron says this is a key issue .
spreading broadband around the country is one of the most important priorities for this government .
labour 's teresa pearce says a 17-year-old constituent died on an adventure trip to morocco .
why have not higher safety standards been put in place ?
cameron says he will look into this .
cameron says there is a new spirit of enterprise in the uk .
this government is backing it , he says .
labour 's lilian greenwood asks what is more immoral : raising vat to 20 % , or not telling people about plans to do it .
cameron says what is immoral is racking up debts that you are not prepared to pay yourself , as labour did .
labour 's siobhain mcdonagh says she was glad to see in the times yesterday that the government now backs labour 's policy of id cards , albeit virtual ones .
cameron says it is interesting that labour is now in favour of id cards
sir robert smith , a lib dem , asks cameron for an assurance that any further tax cuts will not be funded on the backs of the poor .
cameron says difficult decisions have to be taken , but the coalition has shown that it is possible to cut spending and cut taxes .
labour 's helen jones says the numer of gps in warrington has fallen since 2010 .
some people have to wait two weeks for an appointment .
cameron says there are 1,000 more gps nationally .
in 2010 people in warrington were waiting more than a year for an operation .
now there is no one there waiting more than a year .
cameron says he will do everything he can to champion companies like rolls royce .
it is disappointing they are planning job cuts .
it is not clear how many jobs will go from the uk .
labour 's margaret beckett says cameron promised , at his party conference , to cut income tax by â£ 7bn .
so just how big an increase in vat is his planning ?
cameron says the government has shown that you can cut spending and cut taxes at the same time .
people are paying less income tax .
if re-elected , he wants to raise the income tax threshold to â£ 12,500 .
labour 's ben bradshaw says people in devon who are overweight are being denied treatment .
was the nhs reorganisation a success ?
cameron says it has saved â£ 5bn .
as for devon , it is getting a cash increase .
geoffrey clifton-brown , a conservative , says 30 babies a year die from meningitis .
there is a vaccine available , but cost is an issue .
will cameron intervene ?
cameron say the government is in talks with the vaccine producer to see if the cost can be reduced .

documents.title: my snap pmqs verdict
text: snap pmqs verdict : a good pmqs , and strong performances from both cameron and miliband .
cameron probably had the upper hand in the chamber , partly due to some egregious quote twisting , but it 's telling that miliband now feels confident about going on the offensive over europe .
more later
miliband says there is no point cameron doing the fight them on the beaches speech ; the last time , with juncker , that did not work .
is cameron for in or out ?
cameron says miliband is asking about referendum he wo n't even support .
maybe miliband should listen to ian austen .
austen said if you make a mistake , you should say sorry .
why wo n't he say sorry ?
miliband says british business will be holding its head in its hand .
on europe , cameron dare n't say yes , and he dare n't say no .
he 's a do n't know prime minister .
cameron says miliband wrote his questions in advance .
it came at the end of a dreadful week for labour .
even john prescott said the party can not communicate its message properly .
when you get a lecture from on english , you are in trouble .
miliband quotes a tory mp saying vague promises about a renegotiation wo n't wash. cameron once said he would never campaign for an out vote .
is that still his position ?
cameron says he has a plan , unlike miliband .
he quotes a labour frontbencher says labour is moribund , and that people do not know what it stands for .
( he is quoting tom docherty talking about the scottish labour party . )
miliband says cameron did not answer the question .
he used to say he would never support leaving the eu .
will he use those words today ?
cameron claims he answered that question .
he wants britain to stay in a reformed european union .
we say we want reform ; what do labour say - nothing .
that is why miliband faces a crisis .
he has nothing to say about subjects like welfare and europe .
ed miliband joins cameron in recognising the importance of remembrance sunday .
it is a moment to remember all those who lose their lives .
cameron is nearly two years into his eu renegotiation .
he has to get 27 countries to agree with him .
how many has he got ?
cameron says he wants various things , including reform of immigration .
but he has a plan , unlike labour .
and why wo n't he offer a referendum ?
miliband says his position on a referendum is the same as cameron 's before he lost control of his party .
why has he lost the support of angela merkel ?
cameron says miliband is wrong about this .
but alistair darling , about the only labour mp with economic credibility , says an eu referendum is inevitable .
cameron says he wants to get more small and medium-sized firms exporting .
the great campaign is opening up new markets , he says .
labour 's tom greatrex says cameron said steel workers should judge the klesch group by their actions .
is it in the public interest for it to take over tata ?
cameron says the government wants the steel industry to survive .

documents.title: cameron at pmqs
text: david cameron starts by saying , with remembrance day next week , he would like to remember the sacrifices made by those in the armed forces .
he pays particular tribute to the 453 people who lost their lives in afghanistan .

documents.title: iain duncan smith 's evidence to the work and pensions committee - snap summary
text: the hearing is now over .
i 'm afraid it was not terribly illuminating .
here is a snap summary .
iain duncan smith rejected claims that people were dying as a result of the dwp 's sanctions regime .
the rules imposed leading to people losing benefits were fair , he said in tetchy exchanges with the labour mp debbie abrahams .
he said only between 4 % and 6 % of claimants were subject to sanctions every month .
abrahams said people were dying as a result of losing money , and she questioned whether the regime was actually getting more people into work .
dame anne begg , the committee chairman , said the committee would launch its own inquiry into the sanctions regime .
duncan smith said spending on pensioners had risen by â£ 10bn over this parliament .
the government took a deliberate decision to increase the value of pensions , he said .
he said he wanted jobcentre staff get more involved in schools to ensure that pupils from the age of 14 learn about the training opportunities available for them when they leave .
nigel mills , the conservative , goes next .
q : are there delays with processing dla ( disability living allowance ) ?
devereux says there is an issue here .
the dwp is addressing it .
dame anne begg says the committee will be holding its own inquiry into the sanctions regime .
it will publish terms of reference soon .
labour 's debbie abrahams goes next .
q : some 2.8m left jsa last year .
how many were sanctioned ?
duncan smith says he has written to abrahams .
the figures she raised at dwp questions in the commons recently were wrong .
sanctions run at a rate of between 4 % and 6 % per month , he says .
some 12 % of adverse decisions are overturned on appeal .
q : how many of the people who leave jsa after being sanctioned leave so for reasons other than having a job ?
devereux says not everyone who leaves jsa goes into work .
duncan smith says he does not understand the point of the question .
q : you can not prove that sanctions are getting more people into work .
duncan smith says the bank of england says it has made a difference .
he says he does not understand whether abrahams is complaining that the sanctions system does n't work , or whether she is complaining that it is working .
q : is n't it a worry that people being sanctioned are just disappearing ?
we do n't know if they are going into work .
duncan smith says he does not agree .
the sanctions system is fair .
q : people are dying after being sanctioned ?
duncan smith says he does not accept that .
there have to be good reasons for someone to be sanctioned .
and this is a contract ; people have a duty to look for work .
the number of people being sanctioned is only 66,000 a month , out of a caseload of 1.27m .
he says abrahams is almost being ludicrous on this .
she seems to think that the whole idea of sanctions is wrong .
duncan smith says , for many claimants , jobcentre advisers will not need to see them regularly .
they will be able to trust them to get on with finding work .
under universal credit , advisers will be able to concentrate on the claimants who need most help .
devereux says universal credit will also ensure advisers do n't have to spent a long time working out whether it is worth a claimant working extra hours .
this will make frontline staff significantly more productive .
labour 's sheila gilmore says the committee visited a pilot , and say jobcentre staff were spending more time with claimants .
but will that be practical when it is rolled out to everyone .
duncan smith says universal credit is a cultural change , and it changes the way the advisers work .
they will have more flexibility in terms of how much time they spend with people .
q : has the delay had an impact on the projected savings ?
duncan smith says the delay has allowed the dwp to investigate the savings more , and see if they are even better than expected .
the dwp has agreed a figure for overall savings with the nao .
q : there are reports some complicated claims are having to be processed manually .
is that true ?
duncan smith says if a single person becomes a couple , their claim might have to go back to manual processing .
q : so if someone starts off simple , but becomes complex , they might have to be processed manually .
how many people are in this category ?
robert devereux says no system in the dwp is 100 % electronic or manual .
it would not be sensible to be rigid , he says .
if a person becomes a couple , some parts of their claim will remain automated .
but conditionality factors may be processed manually .
robert devereux tv
q : what are the stages for rolling out universal credit ?
duncan smith says the dwp does envisage it being fully rolled out by the end of 2018 .
it will be rolled out nationally from february next year , starting with single people , then moving onto couple and families .
labour 's teresa pearce goes next .
q : when is the nao doing its next report on universal credit ?
mike driver says it is due later this month .
a public accounts committee hearing has been scheduled for december .
robert devereux says the dwp has to agree the facts in the report .
it does not always agree with the nao 's opinions .
pearce asks about a â£ 40m figure in the dwp 's annual report .
what is it ?
driver says he is not sure .
he will sent the committee a note .
pearce says the accountant in me made her out the figure .
it has doubled .
dame anne begg goes next .
q : the dwp has made poor progress at ending off-payroll payment arrangements for staff .
only 15 % of those contracts have been ended .
why is so performance so poor ?
mike driver says this issue has now been addressed .
q : so is there no one working for dwp now on a contract who is not paying the correct amount of tax ?
yes , says driver .
he can give that assurance .
q : you are looking for a commercial partner for remploy ?
what is happening on that ?
duncan smith says thornton is talking about remploy employment services .
that is separate from the remploy factories .
robert devereux says the dwp wants it to have a commercial partner to put it on a more sustainable basis .
q : how will they make money ?
in the same way as work programme partners , says duncan smith ; by getting people into work .
q : but , if it is going to be successful , why does it need a â£ 30m government subsidy ?
duncan smith says these activities have always had a government subsidy .
q : so the government will pay a subsidy , and the private sector partner will make a profit ?
duncan smith says this arrangement will ensure that the organisation has a higher turnover , and helps more people .
mike thornton , the lib dem , goes next .
q : the employment rate for the disabled is 27.9 % .
that includes people with mental health difficulties .
is this just a funding issue ?
or do we need to look at this in a different way ?
duncan smith says the rate of employment has improved .
but the employment gap between able-bodied people and people with disabilities , currently about 33 % , is still too high , he says .
he says about two years ago he attended a conference on this , with groups representing the disabled .
they told him that the problem was the attitude of business .
as soon as the idea of employing a disabled person was floated , they thought of the problem .
yet the evidence shows that disabled people are more productive , stay longer and work harder , he says .
he says the dwp set up a disability confident campaign to change attitudes .
it is making a difference .
but he would like to do more , and to almost make that a personalised scheme for employers .
q : if this saves the treasury money , can you put more funds into it ?
duncan smith says he is looking at this .
q : can it save the treasury money ?
ultimately that 's my view , says duncan smith .
but he also wants to get more disabled people into work to create a more cohesive society .
duncan smith says anxiety and depression are treatable conditions .
the dwp needs to do more pro-actively to help people get treatment .
the coalition is trying to address this , he says .
he says in other countries employers are much more pro-active in trying to help when a worker first goes off sick .
the dwp is trying to adopt this approach , he says .
there is more to be done .
duncan smith says , under the current system , if a lone parent gets a job , jobcentre staff no longer have any dealings with her .
so , if she is working 16 hours a week and is offered extra hours , there is no one to help her decide whether or not she will be better off taking the job .
under universal credit , that decision should be simpler , duncan smith says .
( he 's implying because it will always be worth working . )
but the key difference is that the adviser will , under universal credit , now be available to help , he says .
that is having a dramatic effect .
and advisers like the fact that they can help , he says .
duncan smith says the dwp is piloting a programme to see if it can identify hard-to-help people at an early stage .
it wants to then work with them intensively .
labour 's sheila gilmore goes next .
q : research into the work experience programme shows that most of the people on the programme would have got jobs anyway .
are n't you exaggerating the impact of this .
duncan smith says he does not accept this .
he says this has been one of his most successful programmes .
young people are literally queuing up to get work experience .
q : but the dwp 's own evaluation said its impact had been relatively minor .
and what happened to the early cohorts who came off it ?
duncan smith says this process does not end if people come off the work programme .
they are not left alone .
they then get more intensive help .
q : does n't that show the work programme has failed them ?
no , says duncan smith .
the work programme has helped get people into work .
it helps them get into work for six months .
the programme is becoming more effective , he says .
the dwp is getting better at working out who the good providers are .
robert devereux says no programme ever gets 100 % of people into long-term work .
debbie abrahams , a labour mp , says that 75 % of the increase in employment is self-employment , and that the average income for self-employed people is â£ 10,000 a year .
the jobs are not out there , she says .
duncan smith says he does not accept that .
more than two-thirds in the rise in self-employment comes from full-time self-employment , he says .
q : what do you do to look at these programmes to see how they could be made more efficient ?
duncan smith says this process goes on the whole time .
duncan smith says the work experience programme had a dramatic effect on unemployment .
now people can do work experience for two months .
previously people could not get jobs because they had no experience .
now half of people on the programme get work .
many get jobs with the firm where they did work experiences .
at first employers say they do n't have vacancies , but when they see the work experience recruits , and how good they are , they change their mind .
anne marie morris , a conservative , goes , next .
q : how have your policies contributed to getting more people in employment ?
duncan smith says the biggest factor affecting employment is the state of the economy .
mike thornton , the lib dem , goes next .
q : can you tell the education secretary to restore funding for post-16 colleges ?
duncan smith says he does not answer for education .
but he will have a quiet word with nicky morgan , the education secretary .
dame anne begg goes next .
q : you want to stop young people 's access to housing benefit and jobseeker 's allowance .
what impact would that have on young people without access to the bank of mum and dad .
duncan smith says this is a conservative policy .
it is not yet a coalition policy , he says .
he says if young people are out of work for two years after school , they have a wage scar on their backs .
that holds them back in the long term .
he says he wants jobcentre staff to get involved with schools to help to ensure that pupils , from the age of 14 , who are clearly not going go to go to university can get on the right track .
he would like to turn the jobseeker 's allowance into a training allowance .
for young people in exceptional circumstances , housing benefit would be available .
q : how does cutting benefits at 18 , 19 and 20 get people to get more engaged with training ?
duncan smith says they will not lose money ; they can get a training allowance .
q : but what about housing ?
if there is no housing benefit , people can not move out of home ?
duncan smith says , if people can not get support at home , help will be available .
but for most people the money will be better spent getting them into work than on housing .
training works .
q : but we are talking up to the age of 21 .
if someone leaves school at 16 , works for two years , then loses their job at 18 .
they might have left home already .
duncan smiths says jobcentre staff now start working with young people before they leave school .
that means there should be fewer people reaching 18 with no skills .
mike thornton , a lib dem mp , goes next .
q : is n't there an issue with benefits subsidising low wages ?
duncan smith says this has been the case all along .
it is the case with tax credits .
he wants the private sector to pay better salaries .
after people have been in work for two years , salaries rise above inflation .
but there is an issue about how employers value workers in those first two years .
in the recession , many firms decided to hold on to staff instead of lay them off .
some workers took pay cuts .
q : how many people in permanent employment are on housing benefit ?
duncan smiths says he does not have those figures to hands , but he can get them .
the minimum wage has gone up recently , he says .
the government says it would like to get it up to â£ 7 , but that is up to the low pay commission .
and there 's the lib dem policy of lifting the tax threshold , thornton says .
duncan smith says this has been an excellent policy .
kwasi kwarteng , a conservative , goes next .
q : what impact would cutting the benefit cap have ?
duncan smith says this is a conservative proposal , not a coalition one .
at the moment the benefit cap is above average earnings .
q : would it save money ?
duncan smith says he thinks it would save up to â£ 135m .
but those are not government estimates , he says .
q : how many households would be affected ?
duncan smiths says he has estimates from the party , not form the department .
he thinks an extra 40,000 people would be affected .
when the cap was originally set , two thirds of those who had been expected to be affected were not affected .
that it because they changed their circumstances .
he says a significant number of them went back to work .
labour 's glenda jackson goes next .
q : you said the proportion of housing benefit claimants in work is going up .
does n't this show the government is not doing enough to tackle the exploitative nature of the private rental market ?
duncan smith says there is a need for a private market in this area .
if people are in work , they are claiming less housing benefit .
that is good .
eventually they will work longer hours , and stop need to claiming housing benefit , he says .
jackson says what this really shows is very low rates of pay .
labour 's sheila gilmore goes next .
q : has n't housing benefit spending gone up more than expected ?
duncan smith says the dwp is saving money compared to the original spending plans expected in 2010 .
iain duncan smith at the work and pensions committee tv ( duncan smith now needs glasses to read his notes . )
dame anne begg goes next .
q : but there is a saving , is n't there , from paying benefits later .
they have to wait seven days now to get jsa .
duncan smith confirms that that is the case .
devereux says that , even though jsa starts being paid later , the date of the claim remains the same .
and the dwp is taking less time to start paying from that start date .
glenda jackson , the labour mp , goes next .
q : where have the actual savings come from ?
duncan smith says some savings have come from the running of the department , from the del ( departmental expenditure limits ) budgets .
there have been some phenomenal savings , for example through using more call centres .
on the benefits side , spending on pensioners has gone up by â£ 10bn .
but working-age benefits have been cut .
the savings are from reductions in the projected expenditure the dwp had in 2010 .
q : how much of the savings come from staff cuts ?
robert devereux says the departmental running costs are â£ 2bn a year lower than in 2010 .
the department is much more efficient .
jobseeker 's allowance claims are being paid more quickly .
that means there are few phone calls from people chasing benefits .
q : what are your plans to further reduce welfare spending ?
duncan smith says there are only six months of this parliament left .
the parties are setting out their plans .
but , as for the coalition government , it is focusing on ensuring its policies land properly .
q : how successful are you being in controlling housing benefit spending ?
duncan smith says housing benefit spending has been going up for some time .
but now it is under control .
it will not be cut under this parliament .
but it will not be going up as much as in the past .
q : what do you feel about the fact so many working people are claiming ?
duncan smith says there has been a fall in out-of-work claimants , but a rise in in-work claimants .
but that is positive , he says .
if people are in work , it is likely their earnings will rise .
figures show that after two years they do rise .
nigel evans , a conservative , goes first .
q : how is thme department doing by comparison with the welfare cap ( the government 's new overall limit on welfare spending ) ?
iain duncan smith says figures will be published at the time of the autumn statement .
but he does not expect to breach the cap .
the department expects to save â£ 21.7bn this year , and â£ 26.4bn next year .
over this parliament it will save â£ 50bn .
q : does the welfare cap change behaviour ?
yes , says duncan smith .
the department spents a lot more time thinking about how it spends money .
the cap imposes discipline .
you can watch the hearing here .
it is starting now .

documents.title: iain duncan smith questioned by work and pensions committee
text: most secretaries of state have an uneasy relationship with the select committee that scrutinises their department .
even if the committee is chaired by someone from the same party , the committee members know that they 're only doing their job properly when they start asking the minister difficult questions .
but , in today 's commons , there are few relationships more tetchy than that between iain duncan smith and the select committee that monitors him , the work and pensions committee .

the fact that the committee is chaired by a labour mp , dame anne begg , does n't help , but mostly it 's because the committee includes some particularly spiky labour mps , and because , though duncan smith may have other qualities , responding well to criticism is n't one of them .
today 's hearing is official about the department for work and pensions ' annual report .
that means it could cover anything .
according to the committee , these are the to it will cover .

overall welfare spending and plans for further reductions off-payroll arrangements of dwp staff contribution of dwp policies to increase in employment rate employment programmes impact on expenditure of changed timescales for implementing benefit reforms : universal credit , personal independence payment and esa/incapacity benefit migration progress with child maintenance reforms local welfare provision housing benefit fraud and error duncan smith will be giving evidence alongside two officials , robert devereux , the dwp 's permanent secretary , and mike driver , its finance director general .
for the record , here are today 's yougov gb polling figures .

labour : 34 % ( no change from yougov yesterday ) conservatives : 32 % ( down 1 ) ukip : 15 % ( no change ) lib dems : 7 % ( down 1 ) labour lead : 2 points ( up 1 ) government approval : -21 ( no change ) according to electoral calculus , this would give labour a majority of 24 .
normally the today programme is the best place to go every morning for essential westminster listening .

but today there was a good case for tuning into bbc radio kent , which has been broadcasting an interview with david cameron recorded yesterday when he was campaigning for the byelection in rochester .
cameron used the interview to deliver his first substantial public response to the reports that angela merkel thinks he is getting close to the point of no return on the route to leaving the eu .
merkel says free movement of labour in the eu is non-negotiable .
but cameron said this morning that free movement was not an unqualified right .
of course there is the freedom of movement in europe , but the point i 've been making is that it is not an unqualified right .
and it is important , we 've already qualified it , we 've said that you ca n't come here and immediately claim benefits .

we 've said that if you come here and claim benefits , that after six months you should go home , we 've said that if you come here and you ca n't support yourself and you 're begging on the streets you should return to the country you came from .

we 've already made qualification , but my view is that there is a lot more we can do to make sure that we properly control immigration into our country , both from outside the european union , where we 've cut migration quite substantially under this government , but we also need to take steps with europe as well .

as far as i 'm concerned the british public are the boss , they 've made it very clear they want this issue sorted out , and that 's exactly what i want to do i 've had good conversations with angela merkel about this , and she 's talked about the issues they 've had in germany with the problems of migration and particularly this issue of people being able to claim benefits .

so look , of course we 're not all instantly going to agree , and of course this will be a tough negotiation , but the point i 'd make is look , you 've got one leader , david cameron , the conservative party who have a very clear view that we need to have a renegotiation and then a referendum on europe .
we have a plan to bring our immigration under control , and i do n't hear that plan either from labour or the liberal democrats or indeed ukip .
because of course if you vote ukip you probably end up with a labour government and no immigration control at all .
we 'll probably hear more about this at pmqs .
first , though , i 'll be covering iain duncan smith 's evidence to the work and pensions committee in detail .
here 's the agenda for the day .
9.30am : iain duncan smith , the work and pensions secretary , gives evidence to the commons work and pensions committee about the work of his department .
12pm : david cameron faces ed miliband at pmqs .
around 12.40pm : mps begin a debate on a labour motion calling for the top rate of income tax to go back to 50 % .
2.15pm : mark sedwill , permanent secretary at the home office , and other officials give evidence to the public accounts committee about the removal of foreign offenders .
2.30pm : the armed services chiefs give evidence to the commons defence committee .
as usual , i will be also covering all the breaking political news from westminster , as well as bringing you the most interesting political comment and analysis from the web and from twitter .
i will post a summary at lunchtime , and another at the end of the day .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .

A Scottish Labour leadership round-up

3.04pm GMT

New Statesman loses faith in Ed Miliband

PMQs - Verdict from the Twitter commentariat

bulletin.text: Rolling coverage of all the day's political developments as they happen, including David Cameron and Ed Miliband at PMQs and Iain Duncan Smith being questioned by the work and pensions committee about welfare reform.
